title: Domain 5.4: Given a scenario, troubleshoot common performance issues.
content:
üö¶ Congestion/Contention

Definition: Too many devices or processes competing simultaneously for network resources.

Indicators: Slow network speeds, frequent collisions, inconsistent connection.

Real-world: High congestion occurs during peak hours when many employees simultaneously stream videos or download large files.

‚è≥ Bottlenecking

Definition: Single network component limiting overall network performance.

Indicators: Performance drop at a specific device (e.g., router or switch), limited data flow despite good connectivity.

Real-world: Using an outdated switch with 100Mbps ports in a network otherwise running at gigabit speeds.

üì∂ Bandwidth (Throughput Capacity)

Definition: Maximum data transfer rate supported by a network.

Indicators: Slow downloads/uploads, streaming buffering, poor file-transfer speeds.

Real-world: Employees complain of slow access when streaming video conferences due to insufficient internet bandwidth.

üê¢ Latency

Definition: Delay between data being sent and received.

Indicators: Slow webpage load times, noticeable delay in voice/video calls.

Real-world: Remote workers experiencing lag in VPN connections due to geographical distance or routing issues.

üì¶ Packet Loss

Definition: Data packets fail to reach their destination.

Indicators: Connection interruptions, poor-quality voice/video calls, incomplete file transfers.

Real-world: Video conferencing apps freezing or skipping frames due to high packet loss on the network.

üåä Jitter

Definition: Variation in latency causing inconsistent delays.

Indicators: Distorted or choppy audio/video communications.

Real-world: VoIP calls sounding robotic or distorted due to inconsistent timing between packets.

üì° Wireless Issues

üìª Interference

Definition: Disruption caused by devices/signals operating on similar frequencies.

Channel Overlap: Multiple wireless networks using the same or adjacent channels causing signal interference.

Indicators: Frequent disconnects, inconsistent wireless performance.

Real-world: Office Wi-Fi affected by neighbors‚Äô Wi-Fi networks set to the same channel (e.g., channel 6).

üìâ Signal Degradation or Loss

Definition: Weakening wireless signals over distance or obstacles.

Indicators: Weak signal bars, dropped connections, slow wireless speed.

Real-world: Users far from AP experiencing slow or intermittent connectivity.

üìç Insufficient Wireless Coverage

Definition: Areas lacking adequate Wi-Fi signal strength.

Indicators: Dead zones, inconsistent connectivity in certain locations.

Real-world: Poor coverage in large meeting rooms or basements due to inadequate access point placement.

üîó Client Disassociation Issues

Definition: Devices repeatedly disconnecting from wireless AP.

Indicators: Frequent disconnects, clients needing to reconnect manually.

Real-world: Smartphones frequently disconnecting due to AP overload or incompatible security settings.

üîÑ Roaming Misconfiguration

Definition: Devices unable to seamlessly transition between APs.

Indicators: Dropped connections when users move around an office.

Real-world: Employees experiencing dropped video calls when moving between office floors due to incorrect AP roaming settings.
